data.body:
@pontiffpublishing 
You may as well put your code into an event listener. This code path is not really _that_ performance critical to worry about the overhead of the dispatched event: If you have so much action going on that it matters, other things will slow down way before it becomes significant.

An event listener that checks for a callback is one line of code, and JS programmers are usually quite familiar with this kind of interface, so I'd say it's sufficiently trivial to get a callback. As for replacing the event dispatch altogether, I don't really like the idea of replacing a flexible mechanism with a more limited one.

Hope this isn't too demotivating in case you've been looking for something to contribute. Since you seem articulate and have been digging into animation - I'd certainly welcome help on documenting it, for one instance - and it would make it easier to use too - to a much greater extent, even :).

I wont have any free time for the next 10 days, or so.  If the
documentation still needs updating then, I will gladly help.  Thanks.

On Sat, May 14, 2016 at 4:16 PM, tschw notifications@github.com wrote:

> @pontiffpublishing https://github.com/pontiffpublishing
> You may as well put your code into an event listener. This code path is
> not really _that_ performance critical to worry about the overhead of the
> dispatched event: If you have so much action going on that it matters,
> other things will slow down way before it becomes significant.
> 
> An event listener that checks for a callback is one line of code, and JS
> programmers are usually quite familiar with this kind of interface, so I'd
> say it's sufficiently trivial to get a callback. As for replacing the event
> dispatch altogether, I don't really like the idea of replacing a flexible
> mechanism with a more limited one.
> 
> Hope this isn't too demotivating in case you've been looking for something
> to contribute. Since you seem articulate and have been digging into
> animation - I'd certainly welcome help on documenting it, for one instance
> - and it would make it easier to use too - to a much greater extent, even
>   :).
> 
> —
> You are receiving this because you were mentioned.
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/mrdoob/three.js/issues/8885#issuecomment-219256814

Turns out, I am off today.  So I'll see if I can do something helpful with
the animation documentation.  If you want to give me some direction, that
would be great.

Funny story:  I could not make it to work today because all downtown San
Francisco is filled with tens of thousands of people dressed up like super
heroes, tetris pieces, and you-name-it.  The Bay to Breakers footrace.

---------- Forwarded message ----------
From: Kevin Pope kevin.pope.ppc1@gmail.com
Date: Sun, May 15, 2016 at 7:44 AM
Subject: Re: [mrdoob/three.js] maybe add callback check to
AnimationMixer.js (#8885)
To: "mrdoob/three.js" <
reply@reply.github.com


I wont have any free time for the next 10 days, or so.  If the
documentation still needs updating then, I will gladly help.  Thanks.

@pontiffpublishing if you are still interested in updating the animation docs... #10103
